content: Former Chinese newspaper in Singapore ***Lat Pau*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 叻報; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *La̍t Pò*; [Wade–Giles](/wiki/Wade%E2%80%93Giles): *Lê4 Pao4*) was one of the earliest [Chinese-language](/wiki/Chinese_language) newspapers published in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) under the [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements). It was first published in December 1881 by [See Ewe Lay](/wiki/See_Ewe_Lay) ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 薛有禮; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *Sih Ū-lé*) under **Lat Pau Press Ltd** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 叻報有限公司). It was published for 52 years, ending in March 1932. It was Singapore's longest-running local-run Chinese newspaper before [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II). *Lat Pau* initially was published in [Classical Chinese](/wiki/Classical_Chinese). In 1925 the newspaper started publishing in [Vernacular Chinese](/wiki/Vernacular_Chinese). The newspaper's first editor was [Yeh Chi Yun](/wiki/Yeh_Chi_Yun). - Infopedia This article related to newspapers in Singapore is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Lat Pau
